title: Authors
text: Marco Smolla. Author, maintainer.

title: An R package for complex networks
code: # Install release version from CRAN install.packages("complexNet")  # Install development version from GitHub devtools::install_github("marcosmolla/complexNet")

title: An R package for complex networks
text: general idea complex networks (sense package) individual group set parameters determines probability share edge certain subsets population. common version differentiates three subsets: parent, direct network neighbours parent, everyone else. probability form connection parent given probability pb. Similarly, pn probability connection neighbours parent, pr probability connect anyone else. probabilities regard different subsets population, add 1. far, algorithm working asexual populations (single parent) extended also incldue two parents version future. schematic depicts new individual joins population (one individual removed). case shares link parent connect parent’s neighbours probability pn, individual probability pr.

title: An R package for complex networks
text: generate complex network, use make_bnr() function. need set number individuals network n, linking probabilities pb, pn pr (see example ). set new network set np=c(0,0), means ID set newborn parent . Take look vignette (Articles top) see networks can iterated simulate network dynamics parameter evolution.
code: # Load library library(complexNet)  # Create adjacency matrix for a complex network ADJM <- make_bnr(n = 10, np = c(0,0), pb = 1, pn = .2, pr = .02)  # Load igraph library library(igraph)  # Convert adjacency matrix to an igraph network G <- graph_from_adjacency_matrix(ADJM)  # Plot network plot(G)

title: An R package for complex networks
text: example plot networks generated make_bnr() different social inheritance, pn, random linking, pr, probabilities. linking probabilities increase, networks become connected. Example figure following code generates similar figure one shown .
code: # Load library library(complexNet) library(igraph)  par(mfrow=c(3,3), mar=rep(1.2,4)) apply(X = expand.grid(c(.1,.3,.5), c(0.01,0.03,0.05)), 1, function(p) {  # Create adjacency matrix for a complex network  ADJM <- make_bnr(n = 50, np = c(0,0), pb = 1, pn = p[1], pr = p[2])  # Convert adjacency matrix to an igraph network  G <- graph_from_adjacency_matrix(ADJM)  # Calculate node degree centrality  deg <- degree(G)  # Select node colour based on its degree centrality  V(G)$color <- heat.colors(rev = T, n = 25)[deg+1]  # Plot network  plot(G,       main=paste("p_n: ",p[1],", p_r:",p[2], sep=""),       vertex.label=NA,       vertex.size=10,       edge.arrow.size=0,       vertex.color=V(G)$color) })

title: An R package for complex networks
text: list articles use complex networks: Ilany, ., & Akcay, E. (2016). Social inheritance can explain structure animal social networks. Nature Communications, 7(May), 1–23. https://doi.org/10.1101/026120 Ilany, ., & Akçay, E. (2016). Personality Social Networks: Generative Model Approach. Integrative Comparative Biology, 56(6), 1197–1205. https://doi.org/10.1093/icb/icw068 Smolla, M., & Akçay, E. (2019). Cultural selection shapes network structure. Science Advances, 5(8), eaaw0609. https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.aaw0609

what: Expected average degree of BNR networks — avg_degree_bnr
title: Expected average degree of BNR networks — avg_degree_bnr
text: Calculates expected average degree BNR network (single parent ) based approximation Ilany Akcay, 2016 (see details).

title: Expected average degree of BNR networks — avg_degree_bnr
code: avg_degree_bnr(n, pb, pn, pr)  # S4 method for numeric,numeric,numeric,numeric avg_degree_bnr(n, pb, pn, pr)

title: Expected average degree of BNR networks — avg_degree_bnr
text: n Number nodes network

title: Expected average degree of BNR networks — avg_degree_bnr
text: pb Probability connect parent (default 1)

title: Expected average degree of BNR networks — avg_degree_bnr
text: pn Probability connect neighbour parent(s)

title: Expected average degree of BNR networks — avg_degree_bnr
text: pr Probability connect individuals connected

title: Expected average degree of BNR networks — avg_degree_bnr
text: Returns expected average degree BNR network numeric value. value analytic result numeric approximation (compare examples ).

title: Expected average degree of BNR networks — avg_degree_bnr
text: expected average degree \(\bar{d}\) calculated $$ \bar{d} = \frac{(N-1)(p_b + (N-2)p_r)}{N-1-(N-2)(p_n - p_r)} $$

title: Expected average degree of BNR networks — avg_degree_bnr
text: Ilany, ., Akçay, E. (2016). Personality Social Networks: Generative Model Approach. Integrative Comparative Biology, 56(6), 1197–1205. doi: 10.1093/icb/icw068

title: Initialising a random graph — init_graph
text: init_graph takes number nodes (n) average degree (deg) generate random graph.

title: Initialising a random graph — init_graph
code: init_graph(n, deg)  # S4 method for numeric,numeric init_graph(n, deg)

title: Initialising a random graph — init_graph
text: n Number nodes network

title: Initialising a random graph — init_graph
text: deg Average degree network

title: Initialising a random graph — init_graph
text: Returns unweighted (binary) adjacency matrix, cell represents presence (1) absence (0) interaction row column individual.

title: Iterating a bnr network — iterate_bnr
code: iterate_bnr(adjm, np, pb, pn, pr)  # S4 method for matrix,numeric,numeric,numeric,numeric iterate_bnr(adjm, np, pb, pn, pr)

title: Iterating a bnr network — iterate_bnr
text: adjm Adjacency matrix

title: Iterating a bnr network — iterate_bnr
text: np numeric vector setting ids newborn (.e. individual replaced new one) parent(s). Length 2 3. want randomly select id newborn (first value) parents (second third value), simply use c(0,0) c(0,0,0). one parent, focal individual connects parent probability pb. two parent values, individual connects two parents probability pb.

title: Iterating a bnr network — iterate_bnr
text: pb Probability connect parent. Default 1.

title: Iterating a bnr network — iterate_bnr
text: pn Probability connect neighbour parent(s)

title: Iterating a bnr network — iterate_bnr
text: pr Probability connect individuals connected parent

title: Iterating a bnr network — iterate_bnr
text: Returns iterated version supplied adjacency matrix numeric matrix.

title: Iterating a bnr network — iterate_bnr
text: just want iterate graph can use np=c(0,0) np=c(0,0,0). However, function return ids newborn parent(s). want keep track ids changed, provide input function.

what: Dynamic networks updating for Pb, Pn, Pr networks — make_bnr
title: Dynamic networks updating for Pb, Pn, Pr networks — make_bnr
text: function takes adj.matrix (ADJM), probabilities connect parent(s), neighbours, randoms (PB, PN, PR), index parent (NULL, default, NPARENT number individuals randomly chosen parent), number parents (NPARENT, default 1).

title: Dynamic networks updating for Pb, Pn, Pr networks — make_bnr
code: make_bnr(n, np, pb, pn, pr)  # S4 method for numeric,numeric,numeric,numeric,numeric make_bnr(n, np, pb, pn, pr)  # S4 method for numeric,numeric,missing,numeric,numeric make_bnr(n, np, pb, pn, pr)

title: Dynamic networks updating for Pb, Pn, Pr networks — make_bnr
text: n Number vertices (population size)

title: Dynamic networks updating for Pb, Pn, Pr networks — make_bnr
text: np numeric vector setting ids newborn (.e. individual replaced new one) parent(s). Length 2 3. want randomly select id newborn (first value) parents (second third value), simply use c(0,0) c(0,0,0).

title: Dynamic networks updating for Pb, Pn, Pr networks — make_bnr
text: pb Probability connect parent (default 1)

title: Dynamic networks updating for Pb, Pn, Pr networks — make_bnr
text: pn Probability connect neighbour parent(s)

title: Dynamic networks updating for Pb, Pn, Pr networks — make_bnr
text: pr Probability connect individuals connected parent

title: Dynamic networks updating for Pb, Pn, Pr networks — make_bnr
text: Returns unweighted (binary) adjacency matrix, cell represents presence (1) absence (0) interaction row column individual.

title: Dynamic networks updating for Pb, Pn, Pr networks — make_bnr
text: important note , although three parameters (PB, PN, PR) probabilities, .e. values 0 1, value (say 0.2) means something different . , PB probability connect parent(s), .e. 1 two individuals. contrast, PN PR probabilities connect neighbours parent(s) random individuals. case small social neighbourhood parent(s) PR 0.2 mean connect large amount individuals remaining network. Therefore, important keep mind value (three) values important individual one isolation.
